name: Section 8 - Security Management (SEC)
applicability:
Applicability
Section 8 addresses the management of operational security in accordance with requirements of an Air
Operator Security Program (AOSP). This section is applicable to all operators.
Individual SEC provisions or sub-specifications within a SEC provision that:
 Do not begin with a conditional phrase are applicable to all operators unless determined otherwise
by the Auditor.
 Begin with a conditional phrase ( If the Operator... ) are applicable if the operator meets the
condition(s) stated in the phrase.
Where operational security functions are outsourced to contracted external service providers, an operator
retains responsibility for the conduct of such functions and will have processes to monitor applicable
external service providers in accordance with SEC 1.11.2 to ensure requirements that affect the security of
operations are being fulfilled.
guidance:
General Guidance
Definitions of technical terms used in this ISM Section 8 , as well as the meaning of abbreviations and
acronyms, are found in the IATA Reference Manual for Audit Programs (IRM).
1 Management and Control
1.1 Management System Overview

items.paragraph:
The Operator shall have a senior management official designated as the head of security with direc ccess to the highest level of management within the organization. Such senior management official,
regardless of other functions and reporting structure, shall:

	(i) Be responsible for ensuring implementation and maintenance of the AOSP; 

	(ii) Have overall accountability for ensuring operations are conducted in accordance wit onditions and restrictions of the AOSP and in compliance with applicable regulations an tandards of the Operator.

The Operator shall have a process or procedure for delegation of duties and assignment o esponsibilities within the SeMS that ensures managerial continuity is maintained when manager ith operational security responsibilities are unable to carry out work duties.
The Operator shall ensure a delegation of duties and assignment of responsibility for liaison wit pplicable aviation security authorities and other relevant external entities.
The Operator shall have a system that enables effective communication of security informatio hroughout the management system and all areas where operations are conducted.

The Operator shall have a selection process for management and non-management positions withi he scope of AOSP, to include positions within the organization of the Operator and if applicable,
service providers selected by the Operator that conduct operational security functions. Such proces hall ensure candidates are selected on the basis of knowledge, skills, training and experienc ppropriate for the position.

If the Operator has external service providers conduct outsourced operational security functions, th perator shall have a process to ensure such external service providers receive informatio egarding security directives and instructions in a timely and secure manner that meets requirement f the AOSP and its associated SSPs.
If the Operator uses an electronic system for the management and control of records, the Operato hall ensure the system provides for a scheduled generation of backup record files.
The Operator shall have processes to monitor and assess its SeMS processes in order to maintain o ontinually improve the overall effectiveness of the SeMS.
The Operator shall have a process to ensure significant issues arising from quality assurance audit f operational security functions are subject to a regular review by senior security management.

If required and/or authorized by the aviation security authority, the Operator shall have a process fo onducting security tests that assess the effectiveness and proper implementation of securit ontrols of which the Operator is in direct control.

Such contract or agreement shall identify the application of specific documente equirements that can be monitored by the Operator to ensure requirements that affect the security o ts operations are being fulfilled by the service provider.

If the Operator has external service providers conducting outsourced operational security functions,
the Operator shall have processes to monitor such external service providers to ensure requirement hat affect the security of operations are being fulfilled.

iosa_map: 1.11 Quality Control of Outsourced Operations and Products
items.paragraph: If the Operator has operational security functions conducted by external organizations not under th ontrol of the Operator, the Operator shall have methods, as permitted by the applicable civil aviatio ecurity authority, for the monitoring of such functions to ensure, as permitted, implementation o utsourced security measures is in compliance with its AOSP.

The Operator shall have a security training program that is approved or accepted by the State an eets applicable requirements of other states. Such program shall consist of initial, recurrent and,
where applicable, requalification training that comprises, as appropriate, theoretical training, practica raining and an assessment of competencies to ensure:

	(i) Personnel, employed by or under the control of the Operator who implement securit ontrols understand security awareness and reporting, and have the competence to perfor heir duties;

	(ii) Flight and cabin crew members, as well as frontline aircraft ground handling and carg andling personnel, are able to act in the most appropriate manner to minimize th onsequences of acts of unlawful interference and disruptive passenger behavior.

The Operator shall ensure personnel who perform security functions, crew members and appropriat perational personnel, as specified in SEC 2.1.1 , complete recurrent security training on a frequenc n accordance with requirements of the security program of the State and, if applicable, other state here operations are conducted or, if there is no regulatory mandate, not less than once every 3 onths.
The Operator shall ensure the completion of required security training by operational personnel i ocumented and retained in a records system in accordance with SEC 1.8.1 .

The Operator shall ensure operational personnel complete security awareness training that focuse n preventative measures and techniques in relation to passengers, baggage, cargo, mail,
equipment, stores and supplies, as applicable, and permits such personnel to contribute to th revention and reporting of acts of sabotage, other forms of unlawful interference and securit ccurrences.

The Operator shall ensure measures are in place to control and supervise personnel and vehicle oving to and from the aircraft in security restricted areas to prevent unauthorized access to th ircraft.

The Operator shall ensure access control measures and security screening measures as mandate y the State are in place to prevent the introduction of unauthorized weapons, explosives or othe angerous devices or items on board an aircraft by persons other than passengers.

If the carriage of weapons on board an aircraft by law enforcement officers and/or other authorize ersons acting in the performance of their duties is approved by the Operator, the State and/or othe pplicable authorities, the Operator shall have a policy and procedures, in accordance with the law f the state(s) involved, for such carriage of weapons.

If the Operator conducts passenger flights, the Operator shall have a process to ensure transfer an ransit passengers and their cabin baggage either:

	(i) Are subjected to screening prior to boarding a passenger aircraft, or

	(ii) Have been screened to an appropriate level at the point of origin and subsequentl rotected from unauthorized interference from the point of screening at the originatin irport to the departing aircraft at the transfer or transit airport.

If the Operator conducts passenger flights, the Operator shall have a process to ensure passenger nd their cabin baggage are subjected to additional security controls in accordance wit equirements of the applicable aviation security authority when flights are under an increase ecurity threat.

The Operator should ensure security practices and/or procedures for operational security personne hat have contact with passengers include behavior detection methods designed to identify person ho may pose a threat to civil aviation and require additional security measures.
The Operator shall have a policy and procedures to refuse transportation to any person that does no onsent to a search of his or her person or property in accordance with the AOSP.

If the Operator conducts passenger flights, the Operator shall have a policy and a process tha ncorporates risk assessment measures to ensure procedures are in place for the transport o otentially disruptive passengers who are obliged to travel because they have been the subject o udicial or administrative proceedings. Such procedures shall be designed to take into consideratio he assurance of the safety of the aircraft during the flight.

If the Operator transports revenue or non-revenue cargo, the Operator shall have a process t nsure cargo shipments for transport on all flights have been subjected to the appropriate securit ontrols, including screening where required, as established by the applicable state(s) prior to bein oaded onto an aircraft.

If the Operator conducts passenger flights, the Operator shall have a process to ensure in-flight,
catering and/or other supplies intended for transport on a passenger flight are subjected t ppropriate security controls as established by the appropriate state and are thereafter protecte rom unauthorized interference until loaded onto the aircraft.

If the Operator controls security restricted areas, the Operator shall have processes to ensur erchandise and supplies introduced into such areas are subject to appropriate security controls,
which may include screening or a supply chain security process.

SEC 4 Security Threat and Contingency Management
items.paragraph:
The Operator shall have procedures for sharing, as appropriate, with the State, relevant operators,
airport authority, air traffic service and external service providers, in a practical and timely manner,
relevant information to assist in the implementation of an effective security risk assessment process.

iosa_map: SEC 4 Security Threat and Contingency Management
items.paragraph: The Operator shall have a contingency plan that provides for a comprehensive and manage esponse to aviation security incidents.

SEC 4 Security Threat and Contingency Management
items.paragraph: The Operator shall have a process that ensures notification to the applicable aviation securit uthorities when an act of unlawful interference against the Operator, a reportable security inciden nd/or a reportable security occurrence has been identified.

iosa_map: SEC 4 Security Threat and Contingency Management
items.paragraph: The Operator should have a process to ensure security incidents and/or security occurrences ar eported to IATA for inclusion in the Incident Data Exchange (IDX) Security Dashboard. Such report hould be submitted in accordance with the formal IDX reporting process.
